awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Understanding Hydrogen Interactions with Metastable Surfaces for Tunable Catalysis Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to transform abundant resources, such as carbon dioxide and water, into energy-dense fuels and high-valued chemicals plays an important role in our pursuit of sustainable energy and chemical technologies.  These processes often benefit from the presence of a heterogeneous catalyst, a solid substance that is able to direct the chemical reactions along faster, more efficient pathways.  Designing catalyst materials with structure and compositions tailored to accelerate the desired chemical transformations is an important area of chemical research.  In this project, a collaborative effort among Dr. Richard Hennig, Dr. Richard Robinson, and Dr. Jin Suntivich targets variation in composition and structure to create catalysts known as "metastable catalysts" since they fall outside of the normal solubility and structural ranges.   The team is examining how to design and build metastable catalysts that efficiently and selectively convert carbon dioxide and water to hydrogen and high-valued compounds. Beyond creating new knowledge that can bring more sustainable energy and chemical technologies closer to reality, the investigators are actively engaged in outreach educational activities. These include a summer internship in the principle investigators' laboratories for undergraduate students and the creation of catalysis demonstration kits designed to disseminate the concepts of atomic building blocks and their role in catalysis technology. These activities are directed at improving student interest in chemical science and materials technology from the K-12 to undergraduate levels, and particularly target women and members of underrepresented minorities to build diversity in the STEM workforce.

With support from the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, a collaborative project among Dr. Richard Hennig, Dr. Richard Robinson, and Dr. Jin Suntivich is examining how metastable surfaces can be structured to control the surface hydrogen interaction, and, consequently, the hydrogen evolution reaction and carbon dioxide reduction catalysis. The surface hydrogen interaction is believed to play an important role in stabilizing the intermediates of the hydrogen evolution reaction and the selectivity of the carbon dioxide reduction reaction. This project exploits metastable oxysulfide nanocrystals as model systems with expanded compositional ranges to enable a systematic analysis of composition, surface interaction and electrocatalytic performance. Combined theoretical and  experimental studies are used in collaboration to verify the structure - activity connection at the atomic level and allows the PIs to determine how to design the surface structure and composition rationally to improve the catalysis performance. Broader impacts of the research result from an improved understanding of catalyst function and design in sustainable energy and chemical technologies.  Broader impacts made through educational activities include graduate and undergraduate student trainings in chemical catalysis research from both theory and experiment sides in the principal investigators' laboratories. Additionally, catalysis demonstration kits are created to visually illustrate how to build catalytic nanomaterials from atomic building blocks and how each different building block can affect selected catalysis performance.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award from the Chemical Catalysis program supported the fundamental research on the chemical transformations of nanomaterials and how the transformations impact the catalytic properties. The team consists of Professors Richard Robinson (Cornell University), Jin Suntivich (Cornell University), and Richard Hennig (University of Florida.) Modifying first-generation (as-synthesized) nanomaterials through chemical transformations opens up an exciting, new possibility to design nanomaterials by offering the ability to control morphology, atomic structure, and chemical composition independently. Conventional syntheses do not afford such control. These designer nanomaterials are promising for applications in energy and sustainability. However, the relationship between the nanoscale transformation and catalytic properties is not well understood. Answering this knowledge gap was the overarching objective of the project.

The research goals of this project were to understand how to manipulate metastable phases in nanomaterials undergoing chemical transformations, such as redox and ion exchange reactions (particularly anions), and determine how to use chemical transformations to control catalytic properties. The team has studied the transformation mechanisms of nanomaterials using X-ray and electron microscopy. The team used this holistic approach to characterize how each transformation step affects the catalytic effect. The results were analyzed by considering how the nanomaterials’ structure, morphology, electronic structure, catalysis, and surface properties are connected, focusing on the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) electrocatalysis.

The Intellectual Merit outcomes include the development of methods to control the compositions of transition-metal oxides via chemical transformation reactions. The team correlated the chemical transformations with electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy, Density Functional Theory (DFT), and electrochemistry. The team also connected with experts to add insights on reaction design and engineering, morphology control, and electronic structure. The team has made significant advances toward integrating these characterizations to develop a holistic understanding of the transformation reaction and its impact on the catalytic properties. 

By studying how the transformation reaction can substitute anions in place of oxygen, the team has developed approaches for incorporating sulfur and nitrogen into transition-metal oxides to produce transition-metal sulfides and nitrides with nanocrystal (NC) or nanocluster morphology. The team found that alkylating agents could be used to remove surface ligands that were left behind from the synthesis. Using the alkylating agents could ensure that the final NCs have the maximum surface area. To support this claim, the team applied X-ray, infrared, electron microscopy, thermogravimetry, and electrochemistry to evaluate how the surface chemistry of manganese-oxide NCs change with different chemical treatments. By analyzing the results between four approaches (bases, alkylating agents, Lewis acids, or heat), the team found that while all four could remove the surface ligands, the reactions between the treatment and the atmospheric molecules could affect the NC surface and leave behind chemical residues that become a surface blocker. Using alkylating agents was the most promising approach by providing the most surface area while minimizing the side reactions.

Furthermore, the team reported new insights on how the transformation reactions can replace the anions without affecting the morphology. To minimize the impact of transformations on morphology, the team found that using materials with similar atomic arrangements as the final phase can minimize this effect and further demonstrated this concept to prepare sulfides and nitrides from transition-metal oxides. This advance has enabled the preparations of new compounds for electronic and catalysis applications, including materials with two-dimensional morphology (“2D materials”). The team demonstrated that these considerations could lead to new nitride-based ORR catalysts and sulfide-based HER and CO2RR catalysts. This result could open new routes to creating non-equilibrium nanomaterials that enable new chemical phenomena, such as NC catalysts that adapt to the environment.

The Broader Impact outcomes include establishing the knowledge of chemical transformations for catalytic nanomaterials. The conducted work helped explain the mechanisms in chemical transformations and find new strategies for manufacturing catalytic materials for energy and sustainability. The Broader Impact outcomes also integrated educational and outreach initiatives. The team has served as mentors to several graduates and undergraduates, including the URM students from the Sloan program and undergraduate researchers throughout academic and summer sessions. The participants include the students from NSF-sponsored Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU).

The team developed the outreach activities on waves and materials sorting. Both have become part of the New York 4-H program’s 2-day event, featuring early STEM career explorations for high school students (Grade 9-12). On the materials sorting outreach, the team demonstrated the concept of density sorting and sent out demonstration materials to the participating students by mail before the event. The survey results showed that the students had positive experiences and became more aware of STEM careers afterward.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Jin Suntivich
